poem:
**A Rare Moment in the Commons**

In chambers usually home to jeers,  
a hush falls like London fog—  
debate takes on a human form,  
gentler than the usual brawl.  
Tears line the corridors,   
softening the edges of policy,  
as reason drapes its delicate cloth—  
a fleeting grace amid chaos' habit.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Vote on assisted dying summons ultra-rare Commons sight: intelligent debate | John Crace Who would have guessed? All too often debates in the Commons are partisan affairs, punctuated by jeers and braying. Where reason is superseded by dogma and ill-temper. This was a very different occasion. Parliament on its very best behaviour. Where necessary, people – mostly politely – agreeing to disagree. MPs heard in silence. Some in tears. Even more remarkable was the feeling". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
